page.title: 05ECOLOGY: CHELWOOD GATE
page.content: The area is situated in the High Weald, on the South Western slopes of Ashdown Forest and attracts high rain- fall due to the prevailing South West winds. At 600 feet winters can be very bleak. The flora & fauna are typical of open heathland with some woodland. Large mammals include fallow deer, badger & fox. Numerous small animals are also to be found, with insects, moths and butterflies. Stonechats and tree pipits make use of the low gorse; the great spotted woodpecker inhabits the woody areas. The most common rap- tor is the kestrel; yellowhammers, willow warblers and other small birds abound. Many varieties of heather and gorse, bracken and ferns have colo- nized the ground level with predomi- nantly pine and birch above, together with alder and oak, hazel, willow and holly.
